IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR V. BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND
70-DR-2023-900051.01
The following matter was FILED on 9/17/2025 6:01:54 PM
D001 GILLILAND BRITTANY MICHELLE
MOTION TO REDUCE TIME TO SUBMIT DISCOVERY RESPONSES
[Filer: AGRICOLA BARBARA HAMLIN]
Notice Date: 9/17/2025 6:01:54 PM
PATRICK CRADDOCK
CIRCUIT COURT CLERK
TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
395 LEE STREET
ALEXANDER CITY, AL, 35010
256-234-4361
patrick.craddock@alacourt.gov
DOCUMENT 288
ELECTRONICALLY FILED
9/17/2025 6:01 PM
70-DR-2023-900051.01
CIRCUIT COURT OF
TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
PATRICK CRADDOCK, CLERK
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR,
Respondent,
v. CASE NO.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND,
Petitioner.
OBJECTION TO MOTION TO REDUCE
TIME TO SUBMIT DISCOVERY RESPONSES
COMES NOW, Petitioner BRITTANY GILLILAND, by and through the undersigned
counsel of record, Barbara H. Agricola, with the law firm of Agricola Law, LLC, and files this
Objection to Reduce Time to Submit Discovery Responses. In support thereof, Petitioner states as
follows:
1. Petitioner initially filed her Notice of Discovery on June 24, 2024 [Doc. 16];
2. Respondent submitted his discovery responses, albeit incomplete, on July 26, 2024 and
July 30, 2024;
3. Since Petitioner initially issued her discovery requests, Respondent has not, in the past
twelve (12) months since the issuance, issued his own discovery requests in this matter;
4. On July 31, 2025, Respondent unilaterally scheduled a deposition to take place on
August 6, 2025 without the Undersigned’s prior knowledge or approval, being notified
only through Respondent’s Notice of Deposition [Doc. 225].
5. Petitioner filed a Motion to Quash [Doc. 231] on the basis of Respondent’s last-minute
and untimely notice. Respondent filed their response on August 4, 2025 [Doc. 234]
which states, in part:
That Plaintiff does not wish the final hearing in this matter to be continued
as the .01 case has been pending since May 2, 2024, and if the deposition
Christopher Blaine McGregor v. Brittany Michelle Gilliland
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
Objection To Motion To Shorten Discovery Time
Page 1 of 5
DOCUMENT 288
cannot be held on August 6, 2025, Plaintiff would have to file a motion to
continue.
See August 6, 2025 Plaintiff’s Response to Defendant’s Motion to Quash Notice of
Deposition ¶6;
6. On August 6, 2025, this Honorable Court granted Petitioner’s Motion to Quash, and
that the deposition must be on a date agreed upon by both Parties [Doc. 236]. The Court
also stated that if need be, the matter could be continued to the week of September 15-
23, which was done solely to accommodate Respondent;
7. On August 13, 2025, Respondent filed a new Notice of Deposition for September 10,
2025, one day before trial [Doc. 244]. Again, Respondent failed to contact the deponent
until about one (1) month before the initial final trial date to schedule the deposition,
which again, was done unilaterally without conferring with Undersigned;
8. Notwithstanding these scheduling snafus, and against Respondent’s own wishes to
NOT continue the September 11, 2025 trial date, as referenced in Paragraph 5,
Respondent filed a Motion to Continue [Doc. 247]. Per the motion, Respondent wished
to have more time to prepare for the final trial as it would be impossible to present any
transcripts of the deposition by the next day. See Respondent’s Motion to Continue
[Doc. 247];
9. Additionally, Respondent’s counsel did not have the availability for the alternate week
the Court offered as an alternative option. This led to the final trial date being pushed
over a month out from the initial trial date to the current setting on October 17, 2025
[Doc. 249];
10. Respondent filed their Motion to Continue the currently set final trial date on
September 16, 2025 [Doc. 268]. Respondent boldly requested this continuance and
Christopher Blaine McGregor v. Brittany Michelle Gilliland
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
Objection To Motion To Shorten Discovery Time
Page 2 of 5
DOCUMENT 288
cited being on the Homecoming Committee for one of the Minor Children, which
Respondent himself admits he has been aware of for over six (6) months. The repeating
pattern here is clear: Respondent is wholly irresponsible and treats the matter before
this Honorable Court as so trivial that a middle school pep rally is more important than
the final trial. Respondent had significant time to schedule around any commitments
he may have had;
11. Notably, the homecoming event itself is not until later in the evening, allowing
Respondent and Petitioner to both be present for any send-offs or other pre-
homecoming gatherings/dress-up. This is simply not a sufficient reason to, once again,
prevent the final trial from going forward on October 17, 2025;
12. The secondary reason cited for this continuance is Respondent’s claim that discovery
has not been issued in this case, despite Respondent failing to issue discovery for
sixteen (16) months;
13. Granting this motion would be prejudicial to Mother and only serves as yet another
tactic by Respondent to continue to alienate Petitioner from her daughter and prolong
this case. Importantly, Petitioner has still not exercised her court-ordered visitation as
set out in the .00 case, ordered in February, 2024. Forcing Petitioner to hastily respond
to thirty-two (32) combined interrogatories, requests for production, and requests for
admissions, most, if not all consisting of multiple-part questions, in two weeks time is
inappropriate and improper. This motion is due to be denied as there is no legal
justification for shortening the amount of time for Respondent to complete discovery
under any circumstance presented in this case;
Christopher Blaine McGregor v. Brittany Michelle Gilliland
Circuit Court of Tallapoosa County, Alabama
Case No.: 70-DR-2023-900051.01
Objection To Motion To Shorten Discovery Time
Page 3 of 5
DOCUMENT 288
14. Petitioner has incurred significant attorney’s fees as a result of having to file this
objection to Respondent’s numerous untimely motions and accordingly, Petitioner is
due to be reimbursed for said fees.
WHEREFORE, PREMISES CONSIDERED, Petitioner prays this Honorable Court
DENY Respondent’s Motion to Reduce Time to Submit Discovery Responses and ORDER
Respondent to pay Petitioner’s attorney’s fees incurred as a result of having to respond to this
untimely Motion.
Respectfully submitted on September 17, 2025.
/s/ Barbara H. Agricola (AGR004))
Attorney for Petitioner
OF COUNSEL:
AGRICOLA LAW
127 South 8th Street
Opelika, Alabama 36801
Telephone: 334.759.7557
Facsimile: 334.759.7558
barbara@agricolalaw.com
www.agricolalaw.com
CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE
This is to certify that I have this day served the following with a copy of the foregoing, by
electronic filing in the AlaCourt E-File System and/or by placing same in an envelope, properly
addressed, and depositing it in the United States Mail, with adequate postage prepaid on September
17, 2025.
Dianne James Davis
Attorney for Father
107 Main Street
Alexander City, Alabama 35010
/s/ Barbara H. Agricola
OF COUNSEL
Christopher Blaine McGregor v. Brittany Michelle Gilliland
